text:
Gold Street, south from (No. 23, right), a point midway between John and Platt Streets, across the latter to Maiden Lane. The 4-story corner structure seen on the right and bearing a 'Cafe' sign is the 'Jack Knife' Building (No. 19); a triangular structure that is a remnant of a larger building, part of which was demolished when Jacob Platt cut Platt Street through in 1834. Past same, and occupying the S.W. corner is a 4-story structure (white) No. 15, that has been occupied by Thomas Prosser and Son since 1845. This firm, the American representatives of the Krupp Steel Works of Germany will move to 120 Wall Street, according to the New York Times of December 8, 1937.

About 1910.

Brown Brothers.

(1)
Burling Slip, west from but not including Water Street.

June 2, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, at a later date. Also shown (background, right to left) is the 25-story Insurance Centre Building, at the S.W. corner of John and Gold Streets; south of same is the Singer Building (with dome). A portion of the South Ferry Division of the 2nd and 3rd Avenues Elevated Lines is visible in the foreground, running on Pearl Street.

June 4, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A detail of the same, showing the 1-story building at the S.E. corner of Pearl Street, and bearing No. 234 on the latter.

June 2, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST
title: Manhattan: Burling Slip - Water Street

(1)
Burling Slip, west from but not including Water Street.

title: Manhattan: Burling Slip - Water Street

text:
(1)

91 to 101 John Street, (97-101 only partly shown) north side, east from and including Gold (left), to, but not including Cliff Streets. These houses were later razed to make room for the 25-story Insurance Company of North America Building. Also shown is: excavation work in progress (south side of the street) on the foundation for the new 28-story office building, No. 90 John Street.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A portion of the same, showing No's. 91 and 93 only. Also seen, prominently, is the 14-story National Underwriters Building, at the N.W. corner of Gold Street. At the extreme left appears a portion of the 25-story Insurance Centre Building, at the S.W. corner of the latter Street.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A part of the same, showing No's. 95 and 97-101 completely. No. 97-101 is at the N.W. corner of Cliff Street and bears No's. 1-13 on the latter Street.

October 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

106-104, 102 (5-story house) and 100-90 John Street, west of, adjoining, and at the S.E. corner of Gold Street. The 28-story building (100-90) prominently seen is known as No. 90 John Street. Also shown (fenced) is excavation work in progress on the north side of the street, between Cliff and Gold Streets, where the 25-story Insurance Co. North America Building was later erected.

May 29, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, from a different angle (not showing, however, No's. 106-102). The 90 John Street Building is seen partially on the extreme left, with the Insurance Centre Building at the S.W. corner of Gold Street. Across the clearance (center of view) is the 14-story National Board of Underwriters Building, at the N.W. corner of Gold Street.

May 29, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)#80 John Street showing the Central Insurance Building.

October 13th, 1930

P.L. Sperr,

(1)
John Street, east from and including Gold, to, but not including Pearl Streets, showing prominently the 26-story office building, No. 111 John Street. Preceding same is demolition work in progress, between Gold and Cliff Streets, to make room for the 25-story Insurance Company of North America building.

May 3, 1932

P.L. Sperr

(2)
The same, at a later date.

May 29, 1932

P.L. Sperr
